H0.text: Mean is the statistic that the scientist should calculate to determine the difference between the largest and smallest masses of food eaten by lab rats in the 100 cages with excess food, based on the one‑day mass surveys.

H1.text: Range is the difference between the largest and smallest masses of food eaten by the lab rats in each of the 100 cages during the scientist's one‑day survey of how much food each rat consumes.

H2.text: Mode is the statistic that a scientist should calculate to determine the difference between the largest and smallest masses of food eaten by lab rats in one day across 100 cages in which more food than each rat can eat is provided.

H3.text: Median is the statistic the scientist should calculate from her data when she surveys the daily mass of food eaten by lab rats in 100 cages that contain more food than each rat can consume, in order to determine the difference between the largest and smallest masses of food eaten.

A4.text: The range is calculated as the difference between the largest and smallest values.
